Banach spaces

When B1B_1B1​ and B2B_2B2​ are Banach spaces, we say that a linear operator T ⁣:B1→B2\func{T}{B_1}{B_2}T:B1​→B2​ is compact if for any bounded sequence {xn}n\set{x_n}_n{xn​}n​ is B1B_1B1​, the sequence {Txn}n\set{Tx_n}_n{Txn​}n​ has a convergent subsequence. Show that if TTT is compact then im⁡T\im{T}imT has a dense countable subset.
Solution.

Let n≥1n \geq 1n≥1 and observe that Kn=T(B(0,n))K_n = T\p{B\p{0, n}}Kn​=T(B(0,n)) is precompact. Indeed, since TTT is a compact operator, it follows that Kn‾\cl{K_n}Kn​​ is sequentially compact since B2B_2B2​ is complete, hence compact since we are in a metric space. For each r=1kr = \frac{1}{k}r=k1​, notice that

Kn‾⊆⋃x∈KnB(x,1k),\cl{K_n} \subseteq \bigcup_{x \in K_n} B\p{x, \frac{1}{k}},Kn​​⊆x∈Kn​⋃​B(x,k1​),

so by compactness, there exist finitely many x1(k),…,xmk(k)∈Kx^{\p{k}}_1, \ldots, x_{m_k}^{\p{k}} \in Kx1(k)​,…,xmk​(k)​∈K such that {B(xj(k),1k)}j\set{B\p{x^{\p{k}}_j, \frac{1}{k}}}_j{B(xj(k)​,k1​)}j​ cover Kn‾\cl{K_n}Kn​​. Notice then that Sn=⋃k{xj(k)}jS_n = \bigcup_k \set{x^{\p{k}}_j}_jSn​=⋃k​{xj(k)​}j​ is countable and dense in KnK_nKn​. Indeed, it is certainly countable as a countable union, and given y∈Kny \in K_ny∈Kn​, for each k≥1k \geq 1k≥1, there exists xk∈Snx_k \in S_nxk​∈Sn​ such that y∈B(xk,1k)y \in B\p{x_k, \frac{1}{k}}y∈B(xk​,k1​) by construction. Thus, we get a sequence such that ∣y−xk∣<1k\abs{y - x_k} < \frac{1}{k}∣y−xk​∣<k1​, i.e., xk→yx_k \to yxk​→y.

Let S=⋃nSnS = \bigcup_n S_nS=⋃n​Sn​. As a countable union of countable sets, SSS remains countable, and it is dense in im⁡T\im{T}imT. Indeed, given any Tx∈im⁡TTx \in \im{T}Tx∈imT, there exists n≥1n \geq 1n≥1 such that x∈B(0,n)x \in B\p{0, n}x∈B(0,n), i.e., Tx∈KnTx \in K_nTx∈Kn​. Since SnS_nSn​ is dense in KnK_nKn​, it follows that SSS is still dense in KnK_nKn​, which completes the proof.
